items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood.  Llanymynech and Maesbrook levels have peaked. Predicted peaks:- Cae Howel 3.5m to 3.8m Saturday evening, 22/05. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower Swale remains in force due to high river levels in the mid and lower Swale catchment, as a result of yesterdayâ€™s rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Further showers are expected through the weekend which is expected to keep levels high. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday evening, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower Ure has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Further showers are possible through today and tomorrow.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high at the Farndon river gauge following heavy rainfall. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days, with further rain forecast tomorrow, 23/05/21. Please be aware that access to Townfield Lane could be cut off due to high river levels. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, Sunday 23rd May, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The flood warning for the River Ure at Roecliffe has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Further showers are possible throughout today and tomorrow.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brokenborough river gauge as a result of rainfall on Thursday and Friday.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible until Monday 24/05/2021.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Saturday will be mostly dry.  River levels are currently falling, but expected to rise again on Sunday evening as a result of further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Sunday, 23/05/2021, or as the situation changes.
The flood alert for the Lower River Nidd catchment has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Further showers are possible through today and tomorrow.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper Ouse remains in force due to high river levels as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is possible. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday evening, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Old Wye Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Hay on Wye, Bredwardine, Belmont and Old Wye Bridge have now peaked. Predicted peaks:- Mordiford 4.0m to 4.1m Saturday afternoon, Ross on Wye 3.4m to 3.7m Saturday evening on 22/05.  
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.4m to 5.5m Saturday afternoon, 22/05
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent catchment remains in force as river levels have risen as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 22nd May. The area most at risk is low lying land around Low Marishes. Further showers are expected over the next few days which is expected to keep levels high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday evening, 22/05/2021 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: The flood warning for riverside properties in York remains in force as levels have risen following recent rainfall. Consequently flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is possible today, Saturday 22nd May. The level of the River Ouse in York is currently 3.2m, and is expected to remain high throughout today, Saturday 22nd May. Further showers are possible throughout today and tomorrow. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Saturday evening, or as the situation changes.

The flood warning for the River Ouse at Naburn Lock remains in force due to rising river levels following recent rainfall. The level of the River Ouse in York is currently 3.2m, and is expected to remain high throughout today, Saturday 22nd May. The area most at risk is around Naburn Lock. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of recent persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 22/05/21. Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to rise until later this morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.
The flood alert for the river Seven catchment has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern.

River levels have risen at the Ordsall river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between today, 22/05/21 and tomorrow, 23/05/21.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Goose Moor Lane at Ordsall, and farmlands in the Gamston and Eaton areas.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 23/05/21. We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall on Friday.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 3.30pm today, 22/05/2021.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further light rainfall is forecast for today and tomorrow.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 23/05/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated daily at 9am, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 18:00 Saturday, 22/05. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 23/05/2021, or as the situation changes.
